_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The City of Salem, Virginia, is committed to the Risk Management Plan (RMP) requirements under 40 CFR Part 68 and recognizes the responsibility to prevent harm to employees and the public due to a chlorine release. Salem's accidental release prevention program integrates management practices, safety procedures, employee participation, process safety and operating information, process hazard analysis and compliance auditing, pre-startup reviews, mechanical integrity, management of change procedures, incident investigation, emergency planning and response and updating practices and procedures. Applicable requirements for Program 3 Risk Management Programs are adhered to. The emergency response program is tailored to the available emergency responders and the City of Salem Local Emergency Planning Coordinator (LEPC). It includes notification procedures and plant evacuation procedures.

The chlorination system for the Salem Water Treatment Plant is used to disinfect drinking water. This water is supplied to the residents and businesses in or near the city. The chlorination facilities include a Chlorine Storage Room for one-ton containers, the necessary container handling equipment, and a Chlorine Feed Room with ten chlorinators and various safety equipment and controls. Chlorine is supplied from four one-ton containers connected to the process feed piping. The container in service is controlled automatically using an automatic switchover device that limits operation to a single container at a time. Plant operators check the operation of the chlorination system at least once every hour during each shift and respond immediately to trouble or warning alarms.

The offsite consequence analysis considers two chlorine release scenarios identified as the worst-case and alternate release scenarios.
